DataElement.preferredName: Computed Tomography Coordinate Aerated Lung Posterior Center Length Measurement
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the measurement of the length of posterior to center of tumor in aerated lung by a method of examining body organs by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis in which aerated lung is visible.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Computed Tomography Coordinate Aerated Lung Posterior Center Length
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information relating to length of posterior to center of tumor in aerated lung by a method of examining body organs by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis in which aerated lung is visible.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A method of examining body organs by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis. :A number or other designation that identifies a position relative to an axis or grid.

Concepts.definition: A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.
A number or other designation that identifies a position relative to an axis or grid.

Property.preferredDefinition: One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has but two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border. SYN pulmo.:Denoting the back surface of the body; at or near the hind end in quadrupeds or toward the spine in primates.:A point or area that is approximately central within some larger region or structure.:Length; the linear extent in space from one end to the other.

Concepts.definition: One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border.
Denoting the back surface of the body; at or near the hind end in quadrupeds or toward the spine in primates.
A point or area that is approximately central within some larger region or structure.
The linear extent in space from one end of something to the other end, or the extent of something from beginning to end.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Measurement; the size or magnitude of something.

Concepts.definition: Annotation used to indicate the size or magnitude of something that was determined by comparison to a standard.

ReferenceDocuments.description: Distance from the most posterior extent of aerated lung to center of tumor
